bibl.title: Letter from Rupert Blue to Henry Rose Carter, September 1, 1917

div1.p: Blue writes that anti-malarial work in Newport News, Virginia, is to be continued under Griffitts. Carter is to inspect work at Quantico with LePrince.

div1.head: Letter from Rupert Blue to Henry Rose Carter, September 1, 1917
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
IN REPLYING
ADDRESS THE SURGEON GENERAL
U. S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
AEB
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
BUREAU OF
THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
WASHINGTON
September 1, 1917.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Hotel Grafton,
Newport News, Virginia.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of the 28th instant, you are
informed that it seems desirable to the Bureau to continue
the malarial surveys in Newport News and vicinity for the
purpose of supervising immediately necessary anti-malaria
measures and obtaining information in regard to the need of
anti-malarial work in that region for future use by State
and local authorities and the Service. The supervisory
work will be continued by Assistant Epidemiologist Griffitts
until the end of the malaria season. Recommendation is de-
sired from you as to how long the other employees should con-
tinue their work on malaria in that region.

After inspecting the work at Quantico and conference with
Sanitary Engineer Le Prince at Newport News and Quantico on or
about September 15th, recommendation will also be made by you
as to the suspension of your field work to enable you to pro-
-2-
ceed to Baltimore or New Orleans in order to make the necessary
arrangements for the Memphis Conference and to take account of
the administration of matters connected with field investiga-
tions of malaria generally.

Instructions are being mailed to Surgeon Grubbs in regard
to the arrangements necessary in order to undertake demonstration
work in malaria in any locality.
